channel.title: How to Give Yourself a Static IP Adress [Portforwarding Help]
channel.description:
[center][size=12pt][u][b]How to Give Yourself a Static IP Address[/b][/u] By: Davidi2[/size][/center]
[b]WARNING: If you do this incorrectly, you will mess up your internet connection. If this happens, just go back to the IP Settings and change both things it back to 'Obtain automatically'. You can easily prevent any errors though by reading carefully and doing exactly what it says.[/b]
When you first port forward, you enter your IP address that you found using ipconfig in the command prompt. This number is usually 192.168.1.10*. [img]http://img820.imageshack.us/img820/4940/92273874.gif[/img] The problem with this is that sometimes that IP address changes. For example, I was hosting my server and all of a sudden all connections were lost. I had no idea what was wrong, and nobody could connect. What happened was that my IP address changed from 192.168.1.102 to 192.168.1.103. This made my port forward do nothing, and nobody could connect. A temporary fix is to change your port forward. But what if you go on vacation, ect?
A static IP address is one that doesn't change. Its helpful for port forwarding and a few other things depending on what you do.
[b]1. Open the Settings[/b] Ok, in order to set your IP address, you need to go to your settings. To do this do:
[ul][li]Control Pannel ->[/li] [li]Network Connections ->[/li] [li]LAN or High-Speed Internet/Local Area Connection[sup]1[/sup] ->[/li] [li]General Tab, select Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) ->[/li] [li]Click properties ->[/li][/ul]
[b]On Windows 7:[/b]
[ul][li]Control Pannel ->[/li] [li]Network and Internet[/li] [li]Network and Sharing Center[/li] [li]On the left, 'change adapter settings'[/li] [li](Right click -> properties) LAN or High-Speed Internet/Local Area Connection[sup]1[/sup] ->[/li] [li]General Tab, select Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) ->[/li] [li]Click properties ->[/li][/ul]
[sup]1[/sup]- If that is not there then you cannot set a Static IP address.
That should bring up something close to this: [img]http://img837.imageshack.us/img837/5040/tcp1.png[/img] [
[b]2. Finding your Details[/b] Now go to the command prompt (run -> type cmd and hit enter) and type [code]ipconfig /all[/code]
[b]3. Changing your details[/b] Now do this: [hr] [img]http://img145.imageshack.us/img145/2359/tcp2.png[/img][hr]
After you click ok you should be all set. Your computer will lose internet for 20 seconds then you need to restart. Now check your Port forwarding and make sure people can connect.
Congratz!

item.title: How to Give Yourself a Static IP Adress [Portforwarding Help]
item.dc:creator: @justinxg27 justinxg27
item.description:
@justinxg27 wrote:

Lol, I think it’s different for me … my IP is 10.1.1.1, but I changed it to 10.1.1.27 for the static IP, and it works and all with no-ip… but sometimes I think no-ip changes my specified IP (10.1.1.27) for my hostname… to something completely different… Or maybe it only happens when I refresh the DUC no-ip program. I don’t know…

Read full topic

item.title: How to Give Yourself a Static IP Adress [Portforwarding Help]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“i0b 0n, post:62, topic:307056”]Just use no-ip.com[/quote]No. No-IP is a DNS redirect, which deals with your external IP address. This is for your router and your internal IP address.

[quote=“IceTICKER, post:63, topic:307056”]Shit fucked up my computer i tryed doing this now my fucking linksys dont work is there anyway too reset the Ipv4 settings?[/quote]If you look in the picture, there is an ‘automatically get ip address from …’ radio button. Just select that and click OK.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

runescapelolz:

but dude this kills my internet connection instantly.

It should die out, you lose connection because you switching your ip, if you don’t want to lose it set the ip to the one you currently have. By the way, if you guys have trouble with this I can’t image any of you hosting a server… This is by far one of the easiest things you can do on a computer… Your more or less just filling in the blanks with numbers already given to you…
